description.plain:
Melissa Jefferson (born April 27, 1988), better known by her stage name Lizzo, is a Modern-Hip Hop & R&B singer. She is a founding member of indie hip hop groups The Chalice, GRRRL PRTY, The Clerb, Ellypseas, and Absynthe.

She first came to the spotlight when she released her song “Batches & Cookies” in 2013. The single then lead to a release of her first album Lizzobangers in 2014. Since 2014 she has been recognized and supported by artists such as Cupcakke, Charli XCX, Parson James, and, Dorian Electra.

In 2016 Lizzo released Coconut Oil – EP along with her single “Scuse Me.” Coconut Oil’s most popular single “Good As Hell” was released on May 11th 2016 as apart of the film The Barbershop: The Next Cut.

In late 2017 she released two singles “Water Me” and “Truth Hurts” in September of 2017 as singles to a possible upcoming project/album.

On April 19th, 2019, Lizzo released her second album Cuz I Love You. The album managed to have major success due to the re-release of earlier singles “Truth Hurts”, “Good As Hell” and “Water Me”. “Truth Hurts” being the most popular single managed to be her highest and first charting single peaking at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 Charts.

description.plain:
On Lizzo’s breakthrough single, she flaunts her confidence after breaking up with an unfaithful lover. Despite coming out in 2017, “Truth Hurts” gained traction after being included in the 2019 Netflix film Someone Great, and reached #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 in September 2019.

Lizzo told People that she considered quitting music after the song came out, but her family and collaborators encouraged her to continue with her career, allowing her to reap the benefits and watch the song become a hit.

description.plain:
This is a single by indie rap artist Lizzo, included on the Barbershop: The Next Cut soundtrack. The song is an ode to self-love, produced by Ricky Reed, who is behind a ton of 2016’s pop confections (Twenty One Pilots, Meghan Trainor, and more).

Lizzo described the process of making the song with Idolator:

It came from Ricky Reed and I. We have such a great chemistry in the studio and I think we had maybe made one or two songs prior. We were still doing chemistry tests with each other. We were in the studio and he was playing this piano riff and he was like, “How does this make you feel?”. I went through a lot of things in my head but it made me feel was like the hair toss emoji. You know, the pink sweater emoji girl with the hair. So I went from that hair toss, to checking my nails. It was a natural statement that came out my mouth. Ricky was like “feeling good as hell”. We just rolled with that. After that everything just kind of came out so easily. That’s when I think our chemistry was really sealed. I just felt like everything’s going to be okay.

I think “juice” is kinda freaky, I think “juice” is kind of spiritual and special. I think it’s black pussy.

description.plain:
“Boys” was released as a single in June 2018 and later, in May 2019, as a bonus track on Cuz I Love You (Deluxe). To promote the single, four remixes were also commissioned.

Throughout the song, Lizzo states that she ‘doesn’t discriminate’ when it comes to men in her dating pool.
When asked about the meaning of the song, Lizzo commented:

From this black girl to the world, I want you to identify with my story no matter what you like in yo’ holes. I want people to feel free, I want people to have fun, I want these boys to know that you could be my next victim… if you play your cards right.”

The song was accompanied with a music video the same day of its release.
In the music video, Lizzo dances in front of the iconic music note wall where Prince commemorated in 1977.

description.plain:
“Tempo” is the third single of Lizzo’s album Cuz I Love You, released on April 19, 2019. Featuring the iconic rapper Missy Elliott, the song is about body acceptance and how Lizzo needs a heavy beat to dance since slow songs are not enough for all she has to offer.

In an interview with Exclaim!, Lizzo spoke about her collaboration with Missy Elliott on “Tempo”:

I’m very fortunate to be in a position where I have access to send Missy [Elliott] beats, and I have the privilege of being like, ‘Yo, let’s get Missy on this track.’ I was really hopeful that she would hop and she did, and now it’s become this moment for me. You know, when the song was first going down, it was more like ‘Finally I can talk my shit about being a big girl,’ but when Missy jumped on it, it really did make it a full-circle moment of being seen by her existing when I was younger. Hopefully I can really do the same for young girls today. But really, I was just making bops.

description.plain:
On the remix of her 2016 single “Good as Hell” from the Coconut Oil EP, Lizzo recruits fellow Boca Raton, Florida native singer, Ariana Grande.

The original saw a revived popularity during the fall season of 2019, especially after her performance at the MTV Video Music Awards, leading to this remix which released on October 25th.

description.plain:
Addressing more intimate singles like “Jerome” and “Lingerie”, Lizzo told Exclaim!:

Big women are pursued for relationships, big women deal with fuckboys, big women are beautiful and loving creatures, and it’s just not talked about, because it’s not the story that mainstream media chooses to tell. I’m not creating a fantasy — if it’s shocking, it’s because that story isn’t told and that’s often because big women aren’t even involved to tell their [own] stories. I just happen to be here in the room, I have a platform and I’m telling the story. I’m not going to shy away from it, I’m not embarrassed, this is who I am."

description.plain:
“Scuse Me” is a song by Lizzo, released as the third single from her debut extended play, entitled Coconut Oil.

Lyrically, the song discusses personal flaws in life and by not being happy inside. The song reflects on the fact that no matter what anybody thinks, it’s important that you are happy and respect yourself.

description.plain:
The title track from Lizzo’s EP celebrating self-love and self-sufficiency.

From Pitchfork:

The perception of coconut oil as a cure for all of life’s problems has achieved legendary, and therefore meme-able, status… As an integral part of many skin and Afro haircare rituals, it has come to represent something very important for black women in particular, who rally around its power to heal from the outside in.

So no, it’s not all about masturbation.

‘Cry Baby’ is the 6th track off Lizzo’s 3rd studio album, ‘Cuz I Love You’.
The song details a parting-of-ways with a boy who evokes a great deal of emotion from Lizzo with his actions; however, she embraces her sadness and frustration instead of bottling it up.

description.plain:
“Phone” is the second single from Lizzo’s debut extended play, entitled ‘'Coconut Oil’‘. The song was released 19 September 2016.

It discusses about how the world is slowly being consumed by its surroundings, specifically technology, and forgetting it’s real purpose. For instance, Lizzo sings about phones and how many people use it for social media, gaming, and many other uses. However, what people fail to realize is a phone’s real purpose, which is to call somebody, and that people can get so wound up in what else technology can do besides that.

In a 2019 Zachary Campbell interview Lizzo says this song was written in 10 minutes. Lizzo also says she was looking for her phone and was ask people “Where the f*ck my phone.” E. Bogart is one of the writers on this song wrote Halo and produced for Sia. Some heard her saying that, and they asked if it was a song and Lizzo said no it’s just something we say. So they immediately stopped the song they were working on, and the producer was told to play a little drum beat, and she starts singing the same line over and over “Where the hell my phone.” Lizzo says that it was Evan Bogart who was kind of her hypeman shouting out ideas of things for her to talk about, this song is mostly freestyled.

description.plain:
Worship was the first ever song written with Ricky Reed in LA.
In an April 2019 interview with Zachary Campbell, Lizzo stated she was not a singer before this song. She went on to say she would rap but sing on her hooks.  Ricky asked her if she could sing and she said a little. He then tested her by playing a few notes to test how high she could sing.
She said the experience was different and she didn’t feel like herself. She didn’t think she could sing that high, but she did, referring to the chorus when she sings “hands to the sky.”

description.plain:
Addressing more intimate singles like “Jerome” and “Lingerie”, Lizzo told Exclaim!:

Big women are pursued for relationships, big women deal with fuckboys, big women are beautiful and loving creatures, and it’s just not talked about, because it’s not the story that mainstream media chooses to tell. I’m not creating a fantasy — if it’s shocking, it’s because that story isn’t told and that’s often because big women aren’t even involved to tell their [own] stories. I just happen to be here in the room, I have a platform and I’m telling the story. I’m not going to shy away from it, I’m not embarrassed, this is who I am.”

description.plain:
“Fitness” is the 3rd single off of Lizzo’s upcoming project.

In a recent interview with ConsequencesOfSound she states what the song is about and how it relates to her:

It’s a celebration of movement, highlighting the power in all body types. The women in this video are my team and closest collaborators including the brilliant director Quinn Wilson. I hope to inspire women all over to put themselves first. And next time someone has a critique about you or your body, say “I don’t do this for you."
